title: Calling Out
description: Student speaks without being called on or outside of turn.
strategies: Use a non-verbal cue (pause, hand signal).
Restate the expectation for hand up / wait time.
Acknowledge first compliant response promptly.
Teach and practice call-and-response signals during calm moments.
Privately confer with the student to identify triggers and agree on a support plan.

title: Low Engagement
description: Students are off-task, bored, or not participating.
strategies: Use pair-share or quick turn & talk.
Add movement or a quick change in modality (visuals, manipulatives).
Connect to interests and set a short, specific goal.
Break tasks into short checkpoints with quick feedback.
Invite students to contribute materials or examples from their lives.

title: Transition Noise
description: Class is noisy during activity switches or pack-up.
strategies: Pre-teach a simple 3-step routine with a timer.
Use a countdown and positive narration of students meeting expectations.
Reset and retry brief parts of the transition if needed.
Designate student roles to guide materials management during switches.
Celebrate smooth transitions with class-wide acknowledgment or a quick choice activity.

title: Off-task Behavior
description: Student is distracted or not attending to the assigned task.
strategies: Provide a clear, time-bound goal and check back promptly.
Use proximity or gentle touchpoint to re-engage attention.
Offer a brief choice in how to start or complete the task.
Acknowledge and reinforce the first sign of on-task effort.
Check for understanding by restating or modeling the first step together.
Plan short, scheduled movement or sensory breaks between sustained work periods.

title: Escalating Conflict
description: Tension rises between students and risks disrupting learning.
strategies: Use calm, neutral language to pause the interaction and separate students if needed.
Validate student feelings while reinforcing class agreements about respect.
Guide a brief restorative conversation once everyone is regulated.
Follow up with families or support staff if patterns continue.
